animalOfTheDay.name: skunk
facts: Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.
They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.

calendar.name: sea lion
facts: They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.

calendar.name: sea otter
facts: They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.
Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.

calendar.name: sea turtle
facts: The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.

calendar.name: seahorse
facts: Seahorses lack stomachs and must eat constantly to survive.
They have prehensile tails to grip seagrass and corals, avoiding strong currents.
Seahorses are the only fish where males become pregnant and give birth.
They are poor swimmers, relying on camouflage and slow movements to avoid predators.

calendar.name: serval
facts: They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.
Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.
Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.

calendar.name: siberian husky
facts: They are energetic and require a lot of exercise.
They are known for their striking blue or multi-colored eyes and thick double coat.
Siberian huskies are a medium-sized working dog breed.
Siberian huskies were originally bred as sled dogs.

calendar.name: skunk
facts: Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.
They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.

randomAnimals.name: saiga
facts: The saiga population has drastically declined in recent decades due to hunting and disease, but is currently recovering.
Saigas are unique antelopes from Central Asia, known for their characteristic, flexible nose resembling an elephant's trunk.
Their nose helps filter dust during dry months and warm the air in winter.
They live in large herds and can migrate long distances in search of food.

randomAnimals.name: zebra
facts: Zebras are herbivores and graze on grasses.
They are social animals and live in herds.
Each zebra's stripe pattern is unique.
Zebras are African equids known for their distinctive black and white striped coats.

randomAnimals.name: mouse
facts: A single pair of mice can produce up to 100 offspring in a year.
Mice have excellent memories and can recognize other mice they've met before.
They communicate using ultrasonic vocalizations beyond human hearing.
Mice can squeeze through openings as small as a dime due to their flexible skeletons.
